body: @echauchot I will take a look at COMBINED mode and update it soon.

I prepared two branches:
1. A branch with both Spark 1.x and Spark 2.x support with three artifacts as we discussed (`common`, `spark1`, `spark2`)
2. A complete clean branch upgrading to Spark 2.x and dropping Spark 1.x support.
I will move the discussion & vote from the dev mailing list to the user mailing list, and, depending of the result, I will merge one of the two branches.
Hmm I don't understand why the python build fails since the commit doesn't touch any python code.
@chamikaramj could you please take a look? thanks

I agree that there is definitely space for maintainability improvements, that's why I asked for a more clear explanation for the goal of the changes. @akedin already did a good job by separating features per commit. So I think I understand some.
I agree with Kenn, maybe it is easier to divide the review in chunks, sorry if this fact + the discussion makes the review a bit longer than expected but please understand that 61 changed files / 6 KLOC of changes is a good amount to review (even if some are easy to understand). So I will do a general review about the first part, the generators refactor in #4087 since it could be merged first. And let this issue for the launcher refactor part (since it seems to require the other changes, I hope you are ok with this).

I think it makes sense to put Generator, GeneratorConfig + the new extracted Generators into their own 'generator' package, out of source and with no util subpackage + make the classes as access limited as possible. This with the possible goal of making the Generator + the model objects independent of Beam concepts (if possible) so other projects can eventually have a 'native' generator of Nexmark by using the generator, e.g. Imagine that someone wants to implement Nexmark on their other systems, e.g. Flink, Kafka Streams, etc.

R: @aaltay @reuvenlax 

Can one of you look at this CP?  This blocks 2.2.0 RC4 due to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3172.

Just a small explanation. There are two main use cases with RabbitMQ:
1. the "classic" one: the user specify an exchange name and type (optionally with a routing key). Internally it uses a temporary queue.
2. queuing case: the user specify a queue name (concrete queue).
The IO is able to address both use cases: the user can specify a queue OR a exchange (name and type).
As it's shared between the `Read` and `Write` I put queue / exchange in the `ConnectionConfig` even if it's not really related purely to the connection. I can move queue / exchange directly in the `Read` and `Write` instead.

In my recollection RabbitMQ is extremely flexible and is intended to satisfy a considerably wider array of use cases than just these two. I also think we should consider the cases for reading and writing separately; they are likely to have quite different APIs and tradeoffs. In general, we should assume that a user has an existing RabbitMQ cluster with a potentially complex topology (a bunch of existing exchanges and queues with bindings), and they want the Beam pipeline to be another citizen on this cluster - i.e. we can not enforce a simplification on the user here.

It may make sense to take a look at the APIs provided by other mature data processing systems for interacting with RabbitMQ (e.g. Flink https://ci.apache.org/projects/flink/flink-docs-release-1.2/dev/connectors/rabbitmq.html, Spark https://github.com/Stratio/spark-rabbitmq, Storm https://github.com/ppat/storm-rabbitmq). It may also turn out that their APIs are imperfect and we can come up with something still better :)
Here we are using RabbitMQ in production mostly with named exchanges and named queues. Let me extend the IO to cover other use cases. Thanks !

Sorry I'm on Japan timezone right now. In the meanwhile, it appears that
the PR has been merged.

Hi @robertwb , can you please take a look?

Yes; any particular installation will typically use only one or two of the great variety of possible topologies that RabbitMQ admits (there are _books_ about designing RabbitMQ topologies https://leanpub.com/rabbitmq-structures-and-layout), but different installations will use different ones :)

Of course, only some of these patterns make sense for connecting a data processing pipeline to a RabbitMQ cluster. It will take some analysis to determine which ones, and how to best express them in line with Beam's principles - such as: avoiding data loss at all costs, minimizing operational overhead and configuration, etc.

RabbitMQ is really powerful and we should be prepared that this IO will rival KafkaIO and PubsubIO in both power and complexity and will take a while to develop. It may make sense to already split this in two PRs, for reading and for writing. I'm not sure which of the two will be simpler. Initially I thought writes would be simpler, but I no longer think so.

On write side, there's a few things the IO could optionally do (not necessarily in the first version, but it'd be good to keep these in mind and design so that these features can later be introduced):

- Use publisher confirms to ensure that all data is really written before the pipeline shuts down
- Use "mandatory" mode and provide a deadletter collection for undeliverable (returned) messages
- Controlling whether a message is persistent or not
- Provide some amount of exactly-once behavior

On read side:

- More sophisticated watermarks and/or a custom timestamp fn
- Prefetching

In both cases, I'm not quite sure who should be declaring the queues and exchanges and bindings, that needs to be discussed more.
Latest commit merged on the branch is d28ee9b  (3 days ago), I think we still have to merge this one.
